Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Structure and Electronic Anomalies of Vitreous Matter
Award.AbstractNarration:
The electronic structure of a material, including electronic energies and wavefunctions, determines its electronic and optical properties. In turn, these properties underlie a myriad of important implications for energy conversion, transportation and storage, renewable energy production, information processing and storage, catalysis, optical devices, and many others. Even if the atomic locations in a material are known, inspection of the electronic structure is difficult because of the need to simultaneously solve for the dynamics of many electrons that are strongly interacting. Amorphous materials, such as window glasses, pose a still greater challenge to the chemist due to the difficulty to determine their structure via techniques that have worked well for periodic crystals, such as X-ray diffraction. Amorphous materials, in particular those made by rapid cooling of a liquid melt, are important in applications due to their low manufacturing costs and numerous unique properties not found in periodic crystals. For example, alloys containing elements from groups 5 and 6, such as antimony and tellurium, are presently used to make optical drives and are the leading candidate for next generation computer memory. Another important example is viscous ionic liquids, which are used to make batteries. The project aims to trace the origin of the unique optoelectronic anomalies of vitreous (i.e., glassy) solids to the atomic motions above the glass transition which, surprisingly, occurs subject to very strict statistical rules. The project focuses on the dynamics of a viscous liquid above the glass transition which is to be mapped onto seemingly different model systems that are defined on a fixed lattice. By connecting the parameters of these models with the properties of specific substances, a microscopic description of glassy solids is expected whereby structure and electronic properties emerge self-consistently.

Solutions to the important problem of the electronic structure of amorphous materials lies at the interface of chemistry, physics, and materials science. These factors combine to create a unique multidisciplinary research environment for participating students and researchers, and for communicating to high school students the fascinating properties of viscous liquids and amorphous materials. Considering the ethnic diversity at the University of Houston and in the greater Houston area, the research enhances the educational opportunities of underrepresented groups and promotes their participation in advanced research. Local writers and radio personalities are collaborating to publicize the societal benefits of the research resulting from this project. In addition to the fundamental significance of the research on vitreous materials, other potential benefits include new ways to manufacture efficient computer memory, solar cells, batteries, optical fibers, and many others.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work has radically revised the microscopic picture of the electronic excitations in an important class of amorphous solids, often called glasses.  These materials are made by rapidly cooling a liquid melt, the same way the common window glass is made, hence the name "glass." Common examples of such glassy solids are the chalcodenide alloys currently used to make optical drives. Containing elements from group 16 of the periodic table—often called the "chalcogens"—these alloys are interesting to the electrical engineer and chemist alike. The chalcogenides are known to exhibit the fascinating phenomenon of switching between the amorphous and crystalline state that could become the basis for the next generation non-volatile computer memory and smart optics. The two states exhibit distinct optical and electrical responses; the ability to switch between the two using light or voltage allows one to encode information. To the chemist, these intermetallic compounds are interesting because their constituents exhibit a puzzling ambiguity in bonding: For instance, selenium can have anywhere between 2 and 6 bonds, subject to subtle variations in density and chemical identity of its neighbors. How can we understand this intriguing diversity of bonding patterns and harness it this to make materials of use in information technology?

Our work has supplied, we believe, a key insight missing in the existing paradigms for the electronic structure of disordered materials. Those earlier paradigms treat the lattice as essentially static; the disorder serves exclusively to randomize the local potential energy, as sensed by the electrons, and enhance the elastic response of the lattice to a moving charge. In contrast, we have shown that the intrinsic structural degeneracy of glassy materials leads to new electronic phenomena. The degeneracy comes about because the number of comparably stable amorphous arrangements of molecules scales exponentially with the sample size and gives rise to structural degrees of freedom not present in static lattices, disordered or not. These structural degrees of freedom amount to local reconfiguration between competing aperiodic arrangements of atoms. The edges of such reconfiguring regions are of particular significance: Note only do they exhibit excess elastic tension, they also host very special electronic states that are robust with respect to lattice vibrations. When exposed to intense irradiation, these special midgap states would be observed using electron-paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy and optical absorption at frequencies below a half of the forbidden gap. Exactly such electronic excitations have puzzled the solid-state community since the 1970s, since such midgap absorption is strictly forbidden in the traditional view of the band theories of the electronic structure of solids. The present work thus answers a long-standing mystery.

The magnitude of the excess elastic tension at edges of the reconfiguring regions is of key significance to the question of the rate of the structural reconfigurations and, thus, the relaxation rate in supercooled liquids. The nature of these relaxations is still hotly debated in the condense matter community. We were able to go far beyond the existing estimates for the relaxation rates that were obtained for hard spheres. We can now predict those rates based on measured elastic constants for specific substances. We have thus succeeded, for the first time, in connecting the glassy dynamics with the molecular force fields. The remaining phenomenological component in the microscopic picture is the excess entropy of the liquid, relative to its frozen counterpart. To this end, we have made significant progress toward a quantitative theory of the configurational entropy: We have mapped the liquid dynamics onto the motions of spin-like degrees of freedom on a fixed lattice, a significant conceptual advance. The present microscopic picture allows one to apply the existing framework of continuum mechanics to systems that are vastly structurally degenerate. This degeneracy would seem to prevent one from defining unambiguously the reference state for elastic deformation. Incidentally, it is the absence of such a fixed reference system that makes the theory of liquids so complicated in the first place. With these advances, a quantitative theory of glassy materials, which self-consistently describes both the structural and electronic degrees of freedom, now seems in sight.
